Award.AwardTitle: EFRI 2-DARE: Enhancing Electronic and Thermal Properties in Epitopotaxial Ge/Sn Graphane Heterostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical: The ability to design new materials in which the flow of electricity and heat can be tailored in a controllable way is fundamentally important for addressing the challenges of modern science and technology. It is essential to numerous fields including microelectronics, optoelectronics and thermoelectrics. Two-dimensional (2D) layered materials open new opportunities for addressing this important need. While the vast amount of research on 2D layered structures has been focused on the 2D carbon crystal, graphene, the goal of the current project will be to fabricate and to understand the properties of 2D layered structures based on Germanium (Ge) and tin (Sn). These Ge/Sn graphane analogue structures offer the possibility to manipulate the electronic, optical and heat transport properties by adjusting the number of layers, chemical composition of constituent layers and tunable chemical bonding between layers, as well as showing great promise for a wide range of electronic and thermoelectric applications. State-of-the-art materials synthesis, measurements and theoretical modeling methodologies will be established for understanding how to tune electronic and thermal transport in 2D materials beyond graphene. Furthermore, we will develop a novel, scalable route towards integrating 2D materials directly into existing semiconductor growth and fabrication technology. Complementing the project's major research goals are its broader aims, which include efforts to enhance thermal science education in the participating institutions, and to increase awareness in local communities of the importance and excitement of cutting edge research in thermal sciences, which has often been perceived as a mature field because of insufficient interactions between the research community and the public. Finally, this multi-institutional collaboration will allow the research team to carry out a joint effort to recruit and retain students from underrepresented groups across multiple scientific and engineering disciplines.

Technical: The overall research objective of this project is to develop the fundamental knowledge needed for enhancing the coupled electronic and thermal properties of Ge/Sn graphane analogues, a promising system that offers the ability to vary the anisotropic electronic and thermal properties along both the in-plane and cross-plane directions by using different main group elements and different surface-terminating ligands. To accomplish this, a novel, scalable synthesis method will be developed for the direct integration of Ge/Sn van der Waals heterostructures into existing semiconductor fabrication processes, by combining the epitaxial growth of precursor thin films on Ge(111) wafers with their topotactic conversion into the van der Waals material. These "epitopotaxial" structures will facilitate a comprehensive suite of cutting edge measurements of in-plane and cross-plane electronic, thermal, and thermoelectric properties of single sheets, multilayer heterostructures, bulk 2D crystals, and different substrate-2D interfaces. These measurements will in turn be supported by first-principle theoretical calculations to verify, predict and establish the underlying principles for controlling anisotropic thermal and electronic properties of these 2D van der Waals heterostructured materials. Elucidating the key mechanisms for controlling anisotropic thermal, electronic, and thermoelectric properties in single and multilayered 2D van der Waals systems will facilitate the development of next-generation electronic and thermoelectric devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to design new materials in which the flow of electricity and heat can be tailored in a controllable way is fundamentally important for addressing the challenges of modern science and technology. It is essential to numerous fields including microelectronics, optoelectronics and thermoelectrics. Two-dimensional (2D) layered materials open new opportunities for addressing this important need. The goal of this project is to understand how to the structure and properties of 2D layered structures can be tailored to control electronic and heat transport along different directions of these materials. A major outcome of this program is that it supported the creation and optimization of a new family of single-atom-thick 2D materials built from Ge and Sn, in which every atom is terminated with a chemical group on the surface. This work allowed us to understand how to tailor the electronic conduction properties of these materials by either adding electronic dopant atoms into the framework, or by tailoring the chemistry on the surface. A second major outcome of this program is that we have established the thermal transport and thermoelectric properties in many different 2D materials, in particular, those that have attracted considerable attention in electronic applications. The dissipation and transport of heat in electronic devices is essential for their long-term stability of electronic materials. To aid in this we have developed new theoretical methods that can accurately predict heat conduction in layered materials, that are in close agreement with experimental methods. In addition, we have also extended these theoretical methods to magnetic materials. A final major outcome of this work is that the team discovered a novel electronic conduction phenomenon in layered, two-dimensional materials. In particular, the team showed that certain 2D materials can simultaneously conduct negative charge along one direction (in-plane or cross-plane), and positive charge along the other direction, a phenomenon that we called "goniopolarity". This behavior contrasts with a single material like a Si semiconductor, which conducts either negative or positive charge uniformly along all directions of the crystal. In nearly all modern electronic devices these regions that conduct positive or negative charge are then integrated together in a single crystal to direct and control current flow and allow for complex devices including transistors, light-emitting diodes, and solar cells. The discovery that layered materials can simultaneously conduct negative and positive charge along different directions of the crystal, can enable the construction of new kinds of electronic devices simply by contacting different faces. More broadly, this program has supported the training of the technical work force. Over the course of the program, this proposal supported the work of 10 different graduate students towards PhDs among the different institutions. This includes 3 female students in engineering, one of whom is of Hispanic-American descent, as well as two female students in chemistry including one African-American PhD student. In addition, this program facilitated the modernization of thermal sciences undergraduate educational curriculum at three of the largest universities in the US (UIUC, The Ohio State University, and UT Austin). Laboratory modules focused on thermal energy storage, thermoelectric energy conversion, and specific heat were developed by the team and implemented in advanced engineering courses across UIUC, UT Austin, and OSU.
